description: From Middle English mynt, m√ºnet (‚Äúmoney, coin‚Äù), from Old English mynet (‚Äúcoin‚Äù), from late Proto-West Germanic *munit, from Latin monƒìta (‚Äúplace for making coins, coined money‚Äù), from the temple of Juno Moneta (named for Monƒìta mother of the Muses), where coins were made. Doublet of money and manat.
The verb is from the noun; Old English mynetian (‚Äúto mint‚Äù) is a parallel formation.

entries.meaning: (with condition) Like new.
(numismatics) In near-perfect condition; uncirculated.
(philately) Unused with original gum; as issued originally.
(Northern England, especially Manchester, Tyneside, slang) Very good.
(UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, slang) Attractive; beautiful; handsome.
A building or institution where money (originally, only coins) is produced under government licence.
(informal) A vast sum of money; (by extension) a large amount of something.
examples: That house is worth a mint.
It must have cost a mint to produce!

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any place regarded as a source of unlimited supply; the supply itself.

verbs.description: mint (third-person singular simple present mints, present participle minting, simple past and past participle minted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reproduce (coins), usually en masse, under licence.
To invent; to forge; to fabricate; to fashion.
(transitive, cryptocurrencies) To create a crypto token.

description: From Middle English mynte, from Old English minte (‚Äúmint plant‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *mintƒÅ (‚Äúmint‚Äù), from Latin menta, probably from a lost Mediterranean language either through Ancient Greek ŒºŒØŒΩŒ∏Œ∑ (m√≠nthƒì), ŒºŒØŒΩŒ∏Œ± (m√≠ntha) or directly. Akin to Old Norse minta (‚Äúmint‚Äù).

entries.meaning: Of a green colour, like that of the mint plant.
Any plant in the genus Mentha in the family Lamiaceae, typically aromatic with square stems.
The flavouring of the plant, either a sweet, a jelly or sauce.
Any plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae.
A green colour, like that of mint.
A mint-flavored candy, often eaten to sweeten the smell of the breath.

description: From Middle English minten, from Old English myntan (‚Äúto mean, intend, purpose, determine, resolve‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *muntijan (‚Äúto think, consider‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *men-, *mnƒÅ- (‚Äúto think‚Äù). Cognate with Saterland Frisian mintsje, muntsje (‚Äúto aim, target‚Äù), Dutch munten (‚Äúto aim at, target‚Äù), German Low German m√ºnten (‚Äúto aim at‚Äù), German m√ºnzen (‚Äúto aim at‚Äù), Dutch monter (‚Äúcheerful, gladsome, spry‚Äù), Gothic êåºêåøêåΩêçÉ (muns, ‚Äúthought, opinion‚Äù), Old English munan (‚Äúto be mindful of, consider, intend‚Äù). More at mind.

entries.meaning: (provincial, Northern England, Scotland) Intent, purpose; an attempt, try; effort, endeavor.

verbs.description: mint (third-person singular simple present mints, present participle minting, simple past and past participle minted)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, provincial, Northern England, Scotland) To try, attempt; take aim.
(transitive, provincial, Northern England, Scotland) To try, attempt, endeavor; to take aim at; to try to hit; to purpose.
(intransitive, chiefly Scotland) To hint; suggest; insinuate.
